characters: AT THE END OF THE BAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then -- suddenly -- everything is quiet and peaceful. The sun rises over a distant ridge, revealing a lonely RA nestled in the valley far below. This place feels safe and remote; a tiny island in an oce of green, far away from the horrors of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK SULLIVAN (45) wakes up and slowly climbs out of bed struggles at first; stiff and sore. Once a rugged cowboy, Frank is now approaching middle-age in the 20th century; Man used up and no longer relevant. But there is power in him, yet. A lifetime of farming has left his body in better shape than most men half his age. Frank makes his way through the quiet house; sad and lon PICTURES of his FAMILY (wife, daughter, & son) decorate e room and line every hallway. But they are nowhere to be s Frank Sullivan is all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank brews a pot of coffee and fixes some breakfast, listening to the silence as it weighs heavy all around... In a nearby window, a GOLD STAR BANNER shines brightly in morning sun; a timeless symbol of sacrifice and loss. In addition, two BLACK SILK CREPES hang over the front do letting us know death has visited this house recently. And on more than one occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is hard at work, repairing a broken fence. Each ham strike echoes and fades, the only sound for miles... Frank suddenly hears a distant rumbling. He slowly looks A MODEL-T FORD appears over the hill, bouncing along at t miles an hour. Frank squints, recognizing the driver--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: For God's sake... The car pulls over and comes to a stop. TOM DONOVAN (40s) climbs out, wearing a sheriff's uniform--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Heya, Frank...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Finally bought one, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nah, belongs to the city. Being mayor has its perks. You should come into town more often. They outnumber horses, now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s not something I care to see. (Then, noticing) What’s with the uniform? Tom glances at his shirt as he pops the trunk of his car.  Tom bends

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah...guess you wouldn’t have heard. I took over for Bill Stevens after he passed.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You're the sheriff, now?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Just until they find a replacement.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I didn’t realize it was legal to hold two public offices.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It probably isn’t. over and lifts out a large BIRTHDAY PRESENT--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Think I’d forget?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Think I need a reminder?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You know, a simple ‘thank you’ would do. This isn’t the easiest place to get to. Frank nods and reluctantly takes the package-- Tom shuts

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s heavy...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s a nice gift, Frank. the trunk and turns to face his friend. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You drove all the way up here just to give me this?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Seemed like a good time to stop by, see how you’re doing...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: And how am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know. You tell me. Frank hesitates, not sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You wanna cup of coffee before heading back?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) Sure, that’d be great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sets the birthday present down on the kitchen count and starts to brew another pot of COFFEE... Tom stands nearby, his eyes quietly roaming-- He sees the GOLD STAR BANNER hanging in the window. And t black SILK CREPES draped across the front door... And then Tom notices a MILITARY SWORD mounted in a glass case; sheathed and locked away...from an era long ago--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: ‘Get that in Cuba? Frank looks up as he pours some coffee. Finally, he nods-

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Thought so. You ever hear from any of the old guys? Frank shakes his head as he walks across the room...

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me, neither. Too bad. I hear Roosevelt’s not doing well. (Takes the coffee) Thanks... Tom takes a sip and nearly spits it out--

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God, that’s awful...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I know. I don’t make it as good as Emily used to. Tom hesitates, then takes another sip...this time without complaint. He nods at the birthday present--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C’mon, open it. Frank takes a deep breath and tears away the wrapping pap ...-revealing a brand new VICTROLA PHONOGRAPH--

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You seen these things? Everyone's got ‘em. Here, let me show you... Tom places a RECORD on the wheel and lowers the needle... Softly, suddenly-- MUSIC FILLS THE HOUSE It floats down empty hallways and creeps into vacant room hanging gently in the air beside pictures and portraits o people who have left, never to return. Frank’s eyes well with emotion--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Emily and I used to dance to this.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I know. Thought you’d like it. Got ya some others, too... Tom hands over a collection of RECORDS. Frank shuffles through the titles, stopping at one in particular-- AFTER YOU'VE GONE by Marion Harris Frank stares at the record, suddenly overwhelmed. He look at his friend and finally says--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tom. Tom slowly nods as the song comes to an end. He carefully lifts the needle and silence fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s new in town?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You mean besides the horseless carriage? A lot, actually. Most of the construction that was going on before the flu hit started up again. Think the car’s impressive? You should see some of these buildings that are going up. The world’s changing before our very eyes. I still can’t believe it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Quarantine lifted?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, couple months ago. Stores are back in business. Church is in session. Even re-opened the school. (Off Frank’s look) Rosaleigh’s teaching class until they find a replacement.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's always amazing to see how quickly people move on...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nobody's forgotten Emily, Frank. The kids tell Rosaleigh everyday how much they miss her. Frank slowly nods, then finds the courage to ask--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How’s the rest of your family?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Hesitates) They're fine. Everyone's fine. I was about scared to death when Rosaleigh got sick, but...she pulled through. ‘Seems to be getting stronger everyday. And Edward's due in on Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) That’s great, Tom. Really.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Eh, we got lucky. I’m just glad the troubles are over.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s what we were all praying for.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah... Tom glances at the GOLD STAR BANNER hanging in the window And the SILK CREPES draped across the front door...

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-it’s just too bad it couldn't have happened a little sooner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank walks Tom back to his Model-T Ford. A cold wind blo through the valley. Tom winces, Frank does not.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You know...we’re having a little celebration tonight. Dancing. Fireworks. Should be a good time. No flu masks allowed... (Beat) You should come. Frank glances up at the cloud-riddled sky--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You may be in for some rough weather...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, well...rain or shine, folks would still love to see ya. (Off Frank’s look) C'mon, no one should be alone on their birthday.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m not much good around people these days, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Disappointed) Alright. It’s an open invitation, in case you change your mind. Frank watches his friend climb back into his car...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Tell Rosaleigh I said thank you for the thoughtful gift.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Tell her yourself. She'll be there tonight. Just think about it, okay? Frank hesitates, then finally nods. Tom starts the engine puts his car in gear...and slowly drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind blows, rattling branches like skeleton bones. Frank is back at work, torquing a hammer to remove a set rusty nails...the hammer's shaft suddenly snaps! Frank falls to the ground with a dull thud. He sits up, himself off...and stares down at his broken tool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pulls open the door and steps inside. A torrent of excited rustling erupts in the stall up ahead... Frank grabs a SADDLE and walks over to his HORSE, its tai swishes back and forth in hopeful anticipation...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hey, Fella... Frank strokes the animal’s mane, wondering aloud--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you say? Should we go see what’s new in town? The horse’s dark milky eyes give him the answer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank soars across the empty landscape, an expert rider comfortable being a spec in God’s country... But then, suddenly, he brings his horse to a stop-- The wind blows, carrying sounds of a modern town just bey the ridge. Frank hesitates, intimidated... He slowly rides over the hill, revealing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A world transformed by asphalt and steel. Buildings are reaching skyward, automobiles outnumber horses... Frank takes it all in as he makes his way into town. His horse sidesteps awkwardly, weaving between cars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATRONS fill a modern bar, wearing faded jeans and cotton shirts; as well as a few lingering FLU MASKS... CHARLIE FOSTER and BEN SANDERFORD (40s, both “regulars”) up as Frank passes by their window...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You see that? Ben shrugs, dumbfounded. Couldn't be...could it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELI PETERSON (60s) sits at his desk, quietly working. Something outside suddenly catches his eye... Eli sets down his pen and goes to the window. His eyes fi with stoic pain as he watches Frank ride into town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSALEIGH DONOVAN (40s, Tom’s wife) stands before THIRTY STUDENTS, writing a lesson on the CHALKBOARD... From the corner of her eye, Rosaliegh sees Frank’s reflec in the window. The chalk in her hands suddenly breaks...

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Donovan? Are you alright? Rosaleigh walks across the room, as if floating on eggshe She peers quietly out the window. And then--

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look! It’s Mrs. Sullivan’s husband! The entire class rushes to the window--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATHAN MILLER (18, town deputy) comes walking down the st with a brand new BOOK tucked under his arm... PATRICK BONNER (32, town deputy) waits outside the sherif office. He sees his partner approaching and nods--

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What ya got there? Nathan smiles and holds up the FRONT COVER-- ATTACK OF TH

dialogues.speaker: RED BARON
dialogues.text: PATRICK (CONT’D) God, not another one. How many of those stupid things ya gonna buy?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I dunno. I was too young for the draft. Sounds pretty exciting... Nathan starts flipping through the pages. Suddenly, Patri gives him an urgent nudge. The young deputy looks up-- Frank Sullivan rides by on his horse. The two deputies st dumbfounded. Then, suddenly, they hear a voice from behin  10.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What the hell’s going on out here? Patrick and Nathan both turn to face Tom Donovan. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Sheriff...or do you still want us to call you ‘Mr. Mayor’?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hell, Nathan, I don’t know. You ask me that every day. Just call me Boss, alright? (Confused) What’s everyone looking at? (Then, seeing Frank) Well, shit. That didn’t take long. INT. LEONARD DUSCHENE’S APARTMENT -- SAME TIME LEONARD DUSCHENE (28) stands in the gloomy shadows of his tiny bedroom, a haunted man living in exile-- He watches Frank stop just outside the SUNDRY STORE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank glances briefly at a SILK CREPE hanging in the wind then opens the door and steps cautiously inside--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROPAGANDA POSTERS still hang on the wall, looming above stacks of RED BARON NOVELS trumpeting the glory of war... Frank ignores them as he heads down the aisle. He grabs a HAMMER off the shelf and walks over to the counter... KAY ANDERSON (40s, store owner) watches Frank approach. S smiles sadly through warm, gentle eyes--

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Will that be everything, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hello, Kay...got a newspaper that’s current? Kay nods and slides one across the counter. Frank glances the BOLD HEADLINE-- ARMISTICE DECLARED; PEACE AT LAST!

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: ‘Guess I don’t have to ask if you want to buy war bonds, huh?  11. Frank slowly shakes his head. Kay rings up his total--

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’1ll be sixty-seven cents. Frank hands her a DOLLAR BILL and waits for change...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You running the store, now?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Yeah, since Daniel passed. It’s been hard. But Spencer’s coming home soon. So at least I have that to look forward to... (Then, changing subjects) ‘Coming to the celebration tonight?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No...don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s a shame... (As she bags his things) May be best, though. They’re saying a big storm’s heading our way... Frank smiles politely and reaches for the bag. Kay sudden tightens her grip, refusing to let go--

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about your boy. Your wife and daughter, too. It just ain’t fair...what happened to you. Frank slowly nods, then backs away and reaches for the do He glances out the window and suddenly stops-- SUE FOWLER (40) is outside, walking down the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s a vision of grace and loveliness, greeting everyone with a smile as she makes her way through town... Sue Fowler has no idea that she’s being followed. Twenty yards back, across the street, Frank Sullivan walk his footsteps in line with hers -- watching her every mov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue Fowler, now dressed in a WHITE DOCTOR’S COAT, comes o of the examination room with REVEREND MORGAN FARLEY (50s)  12.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't worry about it, Morgan. Should clear up in a week or two.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sue. I can always count on you to put my mind at ease.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It’s not the flu.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: God, what a relief... They turn a corner and suddenly stop dead in their tracks shocked to see Frank Sullivan standing near the door--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Frank...I didn’t hear you come in. Have you been here long?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not really. (To Reverend Farley) How are you, Morgan?

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: I’m well, Frank. And you? Frank hesitates, then shrugs. Farley steps closer-- REVEREND FARLEY (CONT’D) I don’t believe we've seen each other since your wife and daughter passed. Frank...I am so sorry. If there’s anything I can do--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: There isn’t...but thank you. Reverend Farley hesitates, then turns back to Sue--

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: I’1l see you on Sunday, then?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Nods ) Bye, Morgan. Reverend Farley tips his hat and leaves. The door closes softly behind him. Frank and Sue are alone. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?  13.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I was in town. Thought I’d stop by.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) It’s good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Farley comes outside and walks down the street. sees Tom Donovan up ahead and goes over to meet him--

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: You're never gonna believe who I just saw in Sue Fowler’s office.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Frank Sullivan. (Off Farley’s look) ‘Saw him ride in.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: I can’t even imagine... (Looks up at Sue’s window) ..-he lost everyone. Tom slowly nods, then glances down the street where a LAR BANNER is being hung above the TOWN’S ENTRANCE... REVEREND FARLEY (CONT’D) How’s the new job treating you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Eh, fair enough. I just hope things stay quiet.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: I’m sure they will, Tom. After everything we’ve been through. (Beat) What could possibly happen, now? Tom turns and gives Farley a look: don’t tempt fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits on a table with his shirt unbuttoned. Sue warm her STETHOSCOPE and places it over his chest... This office, like everything else in town, reflects a wor in transition; the old giving way to the new. X-RAYS and MICROSCOPES, VACCINES and ASPIRIN BOTTLES...al mingle with crude instruments from an earlier time.  14.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Take a deep breath... (Frank inhales/exhales) How have you been feeling?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fine, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Any symptoms I should be worried about. Fever? Headaches? Frank slowly shakes his head as Sue listens to his heartb their faces just inches apart. Sue suddenly pulls away-- SUE (CONT’D) Roll up your sleeve, please. Frank tugs at the arm of his shirt. Sue wraps a BLOOD PRESSURE CUFF around his bicep...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: ‘Hear your nephew’s coming home...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: My sister tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, just saw her. Sue squeezes the pump, tightening around Frank’s arm...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You know, I was pretty heartbroken when George and I realized we couldn’t have children. But watching all those mothers send their boys off to war...I don’t know...made me feel like maybe it was a blessing in disguise... (Then, off Frank’s look) I’m happy for her. She could use a little joy. We all could... Sue checks the redial and unfastens the cuff-- SUE (CONT’D) Congratulations, you’re in better shape than most teenagers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I bet you say that to all your patients.  15. Sue smiles and begins to put her things away...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Are you worried about anything in particular, Frank? Frank shrugs, something clearly on his mind. Sue glances the WEDDING BAND on his right ring finger--

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How long has it been?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) Almost a year. Sue steps forward, choosing her words carefully--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I know it’s natural to worry when people you've lived with get sick, but if you’re not showing any symptoms by now, then...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m in the clear?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: In a manner of speaking. Frank slowly nods. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Have there been any recent cases?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Not for awhile. Things are getting back to normal. Sore throats. Broken bones. That sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Think you'll stay on?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I honestly don’t know. We’ll see what happens when the boys come home. It’s one thing for a nurse to take over when all the male doctors have been drafted. Or killed. But making it permanent is something else entirely. Frank glances across the room, where a portrait of the to late PHYSICIAN (60s) still hangs on the wall. BEAT.  16.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You should stay. People know you, trust you...you’re good at it.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Frank. They sit together in silence and the tension quickly retu Suddenly, the sound of distant SINGING fills the air... Frank and Sue stand up and go to the window-- A group of CIVIL WAR VETERANS (all 70s) are standing outs singing WHEN JOHNNY COMES MARCHING HOME; Written by a different generation fighting a different wa the lyrics seem as timely as ever. These dying veterans - their voices old, but resolute -- bear witness to the mos universal of truths: Dwell on the past and you'll lose an eye. Forget the past and you'll lose both. SUE (CONT’D) I remember when you left with President Roosevelt all those years ago. We sang the same song, then. We've really been through a lot, haven't we? An epidemic and a war .--all in the same year.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s the way it’s always been... Frank stares out the window and sees Eli Peterson on the street. Once again, we sense the two men have history...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I was in the Philippines, we lost six men to measles for every one we lost in combat. Soldiers sleep in close quarters. They board trains. They travel all over the world. If you want to spread a disease...all you need is a war. Frank notices the LARGE BANNER being hung at the edge of town. Then he shifts his glance to a familiar building--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s Leonard doing?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He stays in his room most days. And that seems to suit people just fine. They’re still pretty angry.  17.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It wasn’t his fault.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I know. But it’s always easier when there’s someone to blame. I feel sorry for him...he’s got nobody. Frank glances at Sue, then stares back out the window. BE SUE (CONT’D) Is it lonesome living all by yourself? I don’t mean to pry, it’s just...I imagine the solitude would be pretty hard to bear.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s not so bad...once you get used to the feeling.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You don’t live so far away. I could cook you a meal sometime, if you’re inclined to accept an invitation...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: George okay with that?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Hesitates) He’d love to have you. Frank smiles, knowing that’s not true. He glances out the window once more, then cautiously steps back--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It was good to see you. Don’t wait so long next time. Frank smiles, then steps forward and gives Sue a gentle h goodbye. She suddenly winces in pain... Frank hesitates, then pulls at her neckline...revealing a mottling grey bruise just beneath her shoulder blade.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Goddamnit.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Frank, please.  18.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I thought he quit that. Sue pulls away and covers herself...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: He didn’t know he was hurting me, alright? He started drinking again when his brother died. (then, off Frank’s look) You’re not the only one who’s lost someone, you know...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sue...

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Frank, it’s none of your business. Just let it be... She steps back, folds her arms...and finally looks at him

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will there be anything else?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No, I guess not. Frank slowly turns and heads for the door. Sue watches hi wishing he wouldn’t leave like this--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Frank? Frank stops and looks back at her. Sue hesitates, then sa

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday. Frank smiles, softly. Then turns...and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank climbs back on his horse just as the LARGE BANNER i unfurled above the town’s entrance-- It's a triumphant declaration heralding the end of war, a well as the heroic return of the town's soldier sons. Frank stares at it for a moment. And then, suddenly, he realizes everyone is watching him... Frank takes a final look at the singing veterans. Then El Peterson. And then, finally, his friend Tom Donovan.  19. Frank kicks his horse swiftly and gallops away, passing beneath the banner as he rides out of town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes to a beautiful clearing and tethers his horse a nearby tree. The wind blows, cold and ominous-- Frank takes a deep breath, summoning his courage. He plac handkerchief over his face...and enters the town cemetery And now we get a glimpse of the true horror of influenza; freshly dug GRAVES and unburied CASKETS stacked row upon HEADSTONES mark the remains of young and old, rich and po .--all dying in the dreaded plague year of 1918. Frank makes his way through this awful place, finally stopping at the graves of his wife and daughter. He stares at his family -- helpless and alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of MODEL-T FORDS park along the meadow’s edge; the bright headlights piercing the dusty haze of twilight. TOWNSPEOPLE welcome each other as the BAND starts to play MUSIC fills the air. Everyone claps and cheers... It’s going to be an eventful evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits in the dark shadows of his lonely house, liste to Marion Harris sing AFTER YOU'VE GONE on the phonograph Now won't you listen honey, while I say / How could you t me that you're going away? / Don't say that we must part Don't break your baby's heart... As the song continues, Frank takes a pair of SCISSORS and clips the front page of the newspaper he bought earlier.. The flickering light of a nearby candle dances in his eye Frank stares at a headline that seems to taunt him--

dialogues.speaker: ARMISTICE DECLARED
dialogues.text: Frank glances at the GOLD STAR. And the song continues-- After you've gone...and left me crying / After you've gon there's no denying / You'll feel blue, you'll feel sad / You'll miss the dearest pal you've ever had--  20. Overwhelmed, Frank lifts the needle and the song abruptly stops. The house grows deathly quiet. But then-- A crack of THUNDER suddenly rumbles overhead. And the aut wind carries the faint sound of distant celebration... Frank Sullivan stands up and goes to the window. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is in full swing. The band plays to the sunset rows of dancing couples welcome the night-- Nearby, a group of men prepare some FIREWORKS, waiting fo darkness so they can rocket them into the sky... As the music pools with laughter and joy, a few TOWNSPEOP notice the approaching sound of GALLOPING HORSE HOOVES... Heads turn as they draw near. Then, suddenly-- Frank Sullivan appears over the ridge, riding towards the his reluctance visible even from a distance. TOWNSPEOPLE gasp, a few nudge each other and point. Frank tethers his horse to a tree at the end of a long li of MODEL-T FORDS. The animal snorts with disgust--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I won’t be long. Frank turns and approaches the crowd. TOWNSPEOPLE come ov to say ‘hello’. Frank smiles, shaking everybody's hand... Sue Fowler watches from a distance-- She’s dressed for the occasion and looks even lovelier th before. A little makeup has put a spotlight on her face. Frank Sullivan notices her right away. Sue's breathing grows heavy as he approaches; her body language a curious mixture of excitement and fear. She waits for him to reach her...and then finally says--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’m glad you came.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, well... (Looks around) It is my birthday, after all.  21. Sue smiles as the world celebrates around them. The last vestiges of twilight fade and the sky grows very dark... But neither Sue nor Frank notice. They’re lost in each ot

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE MEADOW
dialogues.text: Rosaleigh grabs Tom by the arm, nodding at Frank and Sue-

dialogues.speaker: ROSALEIGH
dialogues.text: Would you look at that... (Tom follows her gaze) I wonder how much shorter George’s leash will get now that Emily Sullivan is dead and buried. Tom glances at his wife with mild disappoval. And then Rosaleigh shifts her glance...and suddenly freezes-- Leonard Duschene is walking along the meadow's edge...

dialogues.speaker: ROSALEIGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t see how he can even show his face...after all the misery he brought on this town. Aren't they supposed to hang traitors? Tom stares at Leonard...and slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE MEADOW
dialogues.text: Frank and Sue continue to talk--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's quite a dress.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’ve had it for years.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Looks brand new.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I don’t get to wear it that often «--do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) Very much. Frank glances at the dancing couples, then looks back at We can see in his eyes what he’d like to ask her. And we can tell by hers that she’s dying to say yes.  22. But Frank is torn both by loyalty and concern over what people might think. He fidgets nervously with the wedding ring on his finger...and hesitates a moment too long--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, look who it is... GEORGE FOWLER (40) steps forward, holding a beer in his h Frank's eyes slant to stab wounds. Sue tenses, on edge.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How are ya, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Fine, George. Yourself?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Pretty good. Frank clenches his fist and glances at Sue. She stares at him, begging with her eyes: Not here. Not now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: ‘Sorry about Dave.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he deserved better. Hell, I suppose we all did. (Glances up at the sky) Wonder how much longer the weather’s gonna hold...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hopefully they’1ll be able to get the fireworks off in time. George slowly nods, then turns to Sue--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: C’mon...let’s go over and say ‘hi’ to the Ludlows. (As they leave) See ya around, Frank. Frank watches George and Sue head back into the crowd, th he slowly turns...and sees Tom Donovan standing nearby--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That new job of yours come with any deputies?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, two of ‘em. ‘Only men left in this town under the age of forty.  23.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You need to take ‘em out and pay George Fowler a visit... (Off Tom’s look) He’s drinking again.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Last I checked, that’s not against the law. Not yet, anyway. His brother died. Cut him a break.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: ‘Problem is when George Fowler drinks, he gets violent. (Off Tom’s look) Sue’s got bruises around her shoulder and collar bone.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Saw it with my own eyes. Tom glances across the meadow, letting out a deep sigh--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Shit. I was worried about that. There have been rumors...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Why hasn’t anything been done?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Sheriff. You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Hey, take it easy. I’11 look into it, alright? Frank stares at Tom as THUNDER erupts overhead...

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me like that. I told you I hate this goddamn job... Tom suddenly turns and disappears back into the crowd. Fr watches him go, then heads the other way... As he walks, Frank overhears PARENTS asking each other wh their children are coming home from the war...  24. Frank looks away, saddened. He glances across the meadow. and sees Leonard Duschene standing all by himself-- The two men stare at each other for a moment...and then t sound of MICROPHONE FEEDBACK causes everyone to look up. Tom Donovan and Reverend Farley are standing at the PODIU

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen...could I have everyone’s attention, please? The music and dancing stop. All eyes turn to Tom--

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As most of you probably know by now, I’m no good at making speeches. But I wanted to welcome you all out tonight...and just say thank you for coming. (Applause, then) This is a time for celebration. But we would be remiss if we did not pause to remember those we’ve lost this past year. So, on that note, I'd like to turn it over to Reverend Farley. Morgan? Reverend Farley steps forward. The mood turns grim--

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: In memory of the fallen, I ask that we observe a moment of silence... Suddenly, CHILDREN and TEENAGERS begin roaming through th crowd, holding trays filled with SMALL CANDLES... REVEREND FARLEY (CONT’D) Members of our Sunday school will be passing by with candles. Please take one for every family member you lost this year, whether it was from sickness...or war. TOWNSPEOPLE start taking candles as the children pass by. Every FAMILY takes at least one; some even take two. A soft orange glow slowly spreads through the meadow... Frank Sullivan looks up at a YOUNG GIRL standing before h He takes a deep breath and picks up a candle... Then, with his other hand, he picks up two more.  25.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE CROWD
dialogues.text: Eli Peterson watches Frank struggle to hold three candles his own. With trembling hands, Eli sets his candle down.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PODIUM
dialogues.text: Reverend Farley lifts a single flame high above his head. The entire town follows his lead. Hundreds of flames rise the darkness, whispering gently in the faint autumn air. Leonard stares at all the candles, haunted and guilt-ridd Everyone observes a moment of silence. And then Reverend Farley takes a deep breath...and blows out his flame. Everyone else does likewise. The meadow suddenly goes dar A devastating stillness hangs in the air...and then the s of SHRIEKING ROCKETS causes everyone to look up-- FIREWORKS explode overhead. TOWNSPEOPLE gasp and applaud, their faces fading up and down with the flickering light. Then, softly and suddenly-- Distant GUNSHOTS pop in the faraway woods...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reverberate for a moment and quickly die away, absor by the loud explosions booming overhead. Frank is the only one who notices. He turns and looks out the thick dark trees, wondering if he heard right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Sullivan’s ranch sits peacefully in the night... A gust of wind shakes the trees like a torrent of darknes followed by rumbling thunder and flashes of lightning. The storm warnings subside and the silence returns. A cal soothing moment hangs in the air...and then-- A YOUNG WOMAN (20s) stumbles out of the woods; her clothe soaking wet, her body drenched in blood. The sight of her should take our breath away. She appears suddenly out of nowhere, like a ghost in the darkness. She limps towards Frank Sullivan's house...  26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young woman breaks a window and comes inside, leaving thick trail of blood with every painful step. She searches frantically for medicine and supplies, but t house is very dark. And her life is fading fast. She collapses on the floor with a sickening thud; unconsc and near death, her blood pooling around her. Outside, a violent crack of thunder promises heavy rain..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as the fireworks conclude, the DOWNPOUR begins... Everybody runs to their cars, but the Model-Ts are trappe Engines start and wheels spin. Nobody is able to get away ...except for Frank, who walks calmly towards his horse - kicking and snorting beneath an onslaught of rain... Frank climbs into the saddle and gallops away, passing sc of cars as they fishtail in vain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes inside and takes off his wet coat. He lights candle and makes his way through the dark house... Suddenly, Frank stops. He can hear the storm outside loud than ever. He sees the broken window first... .+-and then he steps in something wet. Frank kneels, holding the candle close to the floor. His suddenly widen -- he’s standing in a pool of blood. A burst of LIGHTNING reveals the young girl on the floor. Frank springs to action, reacting on pure instinct-- He picks the girl up and sets her down on the kitchen tab knocking everything to the ground in order to make room.. He tears off her clothes and finds three bullet wounds; t in the arm, one in the thigh. Blood pours out of her body Frank wraps a tourniquet above each wound, then finds the girl's pulse...so faint, it’s barely even there. Frank stares at her, overwhelmed. This is as far as his knowledge will take him. He needs help. He needs...a doct  27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank gallops through the pouring rain, weaving between trapped cars and foggy headlight beams-- He knocks on windows and waits for them to crack. Then he peers inside, hoping to find Sue Fowler... Finally, Frank reaches the right car. He knocks loudly an waits. The window opens...George Fowler peers out--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Frank? What the hell...? Frank rides around to the other side of the car. He knock the window...it immediately rolls down--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I need your help...a woman’s hurt.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What? How?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Shot. Pretty bad. C’mon, I’1l1 explain on the way...please. Sue nods and opens her door, stepping out into the rain..

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sue! What the hell are you doing?! Frank pulls her up onto his horse and they gallop away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Sue come inside, both soaking wet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know where she came from. She was here when I got home...can you help her? Sue rushes to the girl’s side and quickly goes to work--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: She’s lost a lot of blood... (then, horrified) God, her pulse is racing...it has to be in the 140s, at least. Is there any alcohol in the house? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Off his look) I need a disinfectant.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What kind?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Whatever’s strongest. And I need a knife...like a scalpel. Frank leaves to gather the items. Sue grabs a nearby cand and moves it closer. It lights up the girl’s face... Frank comes back just in time for her to say-- SUE (CONT’D) She looks like Kathryn. Frank hesitates, then sets two bottles of WHISKEY and a S KNIFE down on the table--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We need to make a splint for her arm. And I need a hemostat...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: A pair of pliers... Frank glances around the room -- thinking fast. He turns TABLE on its side and breaks off one of the LEGS.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Will this work?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Looks up) Yes, thank you. Sue fashions a splint and wraps the girl’s arm. Frank lea the room and returns with a pair of PLIERS-- SUE (CONT’D) Thank you. Sue soaks a towel and cleans the girl’s wounds... SUE (CONT’D) Do you know your blood type?  29.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hopefully someone in town does... Sue picks up the pliers and douses them with whiskey--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Is that clean enough?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It’s gonna have to be. Sue digs into the girl’s thigh. Frank watches with steely resolve as the pliers go deeper...and deeper--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Re: Bullet) Can you get it?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: It’s up against the femoral artery. If that gets severed, she’ll bleed to death.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She's doing that already. Sue nods...and pushes the pliers in just that much deeper She pulls out a thick BLACK SLUG; mangled and disgusting. Frank grabs his rifle and stands guard near the window... after all, the killers may still be out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has stopped. The sun begins to rise, revealing a beautiful landscape and a majestic morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits in a chair, holding his rifle in his arms. He hears approaching footsteps...and slowly looks up. Sue Fowler comes into the room, wiping her hands on a blo towel. She stares at Frank, exhausted. Then quietly says-

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: She’s alive. Frank slowly nods and gets to his feet...  30. SUE (CONT’D) Her clothes are ruined, though. Do you have anything...she could use?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Hesitates) Emily’s things are still upstairs. Second bedroom closet.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Okay. What should I take?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) Doesn’t matter. Sue slowly nods, then hands him a LIST--

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT, 'D)
dialogues.text: Think you could go into town? I need some things from my clinic. Frank nods, pocketing the list. He holds up his rifle--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You know how to use this? Sue hesitates, then nods. Frank hands her the gun--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Safety’s off. All you gotta do is aim...and pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Please hurry. Frank turns and charges out the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Sullivan gallops into town, heading for Sue’s clini TOWNSPEOPLE watch, alarmed by his urgent pace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue Fowler stands in the quiet room, staring respectfully clothes that once belonged to Emily Sullivan. She goes through the dresses, one at a time...finally selecting one that seems safe and appropriate.  31. INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE -- SAME TIME Frank fills a BLACK MEDICAL BAG with supplies... He hears a pair of boots come thunking up the stairs, followed by Tom Donovan’s voice at the door--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Saw your horse outside. You know, for a guy who supposedly doesn’t like coming into town, you sure are doing it a lot, lately. Frank glances at Tom, then continues filling the bag...

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You aimin’ to rob the place?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Taking some things out to Sue...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: My ranch.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Oh, good. That oughta make for some nice Sunday gossip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: There was a shooting last night, Tom...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What? Where?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Not sure. A girl showed up on my doorstep covered in blood.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You're serious?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You think I'd make this up?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Is she from around here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don’t think so.  32.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: But she’s alive?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Last I checked. (Then, urgently) I need you to come with me. Now.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Alright, let me get my horse.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do it quickly. Tom nods and leaves the room. Frank grabs the last few th on Sue’s list...and follows close behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Nathan come outside and watch Tom climb onto horse. He rides over to meet them--

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: What’s going on, Boss?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I need you boys to start gathering a search party...

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: This early? It’s Saturday...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You get twelve able-bodied men as fast as you can and head out to the Sullivan Ranch. You hear? Nathan looks dumbfounded. Patrick slowly nods--

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Tom kicks his horse and meets Frank in the middle of the street. Together, they gallop out of town... INT. LEONARD DUSCHENE’S ROOM -- CONTINUOUS Leonard watches Frank and Tom disappear over the ridge. H eyes narrow -- sensing trouble in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue lays a BLANKET over the girl’s trembling body. She suddenly hears faint horse hooves, approaching fast...  33. She grabs Frank’s rifle and heads for the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue steps outside just as Frank and Tom appear over the ridge. They bring their horses to a sudden stop--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Did you get everything? Frank hands her the medical bag. Sue opens it and checks-

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How is she?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Not good... Sue snaps the bag shut and hurries back to the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom stares at the blood stained floor as Sue inflates a B PRESSURE CUFF around the girl’s arm and checks the redial

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Jesus, she’s 70 over 30.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: That she’s hanging by a thread. (Checks the girl’s pulse) Her heart can’t keep beating like this. It’s gonna give out... (Then, to Tom) You don’t know your blood type by any chance, do you?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: There are different kinds? (Off her look) What does it even matter?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: The wrong kind will kill her. That's why it matters. And since she’s unconscious, we have to find someone who’s O-negative... (Off Tom’s look) They're called universal donors. They’re very rare...and they can give blood to anybody.  34.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’1l ask around town, but who would even know such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Soldiers. Anyone who’s met with a draft board knows if they’re able to transfuse blood.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Transfuse blood? We never did anything like that in Cuba.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: We did in the Philippines.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (Grimly ) Yeah, I bet. (Then, stepping closer) I can’t hardly believe it... somebody shot her?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Twice in the arm. Once in the leg.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: All on the same side, too. (To Frank) What does that tell you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She wasn’t running away...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Wasn’t facing ‘em either. Tom suddenly notices the mangled slug sitting on the tabl

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (To Frank) That look like any bullet you've ever seen? Frank hesitates, then slowly shakes his head. Tom turns a crosses the room, staring at the broken window--

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How'd she get all the way out here?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Tom. I didn’t have a chance to ask her.  35. Tom peers out the window and sees Patrick and Nathan in t distance, leading a SEARCH PARTY towards Frank’s property

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: (Dramatic Beat) Let’s find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The search party charges through the woods; TWELVE MEN on HORSEBACK armed with GUNS and SCENT-SNIFFING DOGS. Frank and Tom lead the group. The others are all MEN we m recognize -- Patrick & Nathan, the Civil War Vets, etc. They keep pace with the dogs, hot on the girl’s trail...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue kneels at the girl’s bedside, attending to her wounds She suddenly hears a knock at the front door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue opens the door and finds her husband standing on the porch. She recoils slightly, then manages to say--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: You’re late. The others left...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That’s all you have to say to me? Do you have any idea how worried I was last night? I didn’t even know what had happened until one of Tom's deputies knocked on our door organizing a search party.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Exhausted) Please. Don’t start. Sue turns and heads back upstairs. George quickly follows

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Branches snap as the dogs carve through the trees. The me follow close behind, hoping for some sign or clue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue resumes her place at the girl’s bedside. George comes the doorway and watches quietly...  36.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So this is the mystery girl, huh? Where’d she come from?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: We don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is she going to live?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well...you should be used to that by now. Sue shudders quietly, but doesn’t respond. George suddenl notices an empty WHISKEY BOTTLE sitting on the table--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Any more of that in the house?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Hesitates) I think we used it all... George slowly nods, then turns and leaves the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Tom emerge from the woods and find themselves a MAJESTIC LAKE, stretching for miles in every direction... Tom watches their dog sniff along the shoreline--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Goddamnit...it’s as if she just fell out of the sky. Frank stares at the TALL CLIFFS towering above the lake..

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon, let’s go... Tom turns to leave, but Frank doesn’t budge--

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Confused) Frank? She didn’t walk on water...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Maybe she came up out of it.  37. Frank spurs his horse forward, charging up the STEEP INCL so severe, they’re nearly vertical as they ascend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and his horse reach the top and level out onto flat terrain. Frank dismounts and takes in his surroundings-- He hears the sound of a HORSE struggling to climb. And th Tom appears; his face ashen from the harrowing ascent.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Let’s not do that again. Frank nods up ahead, where the road suddenly bends--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If you were waiting to ambush someone, where would you be? Tom looks around for a moment, then points--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: There. Frank takes position in the grass. He stares at the road shifts his weight...something crunches beneath his feet-- Frank picks up a_handful of empty bullet shells.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Frank walks over to the cliff’s edge. He stares at the ground, looking for something...and then he finds it-- Faint TIRE TRACKS, like a decaying fossil; nearly washed by the rain, leading right over the edge of the cliff... Frank leans over and peers at the water below; the sun da across the surface like a fortune of golden coins. Beneath the water, oscillating between glimmers of sunlig is a refracted image of a LARGE, BLACK OBJECT...

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That what I think it is? Frank hesitates, then slowly nods--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah...  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George sits at Frank’s desk, opening drawers. He searches vigorously, but doesn’t find what he’s looking for. Instead, he discovers a file of NEWSPAPER CLIPPINGS-- The article Frank saved earlier is at the top of the pile .--along with a hand written LETTER, worn and well read-- “Dear Mr. & Mrs. Sullivan, I deeply regret to inform you your son, Private William Sullivan, died this afternoon.. George skims the letter, then flips through the articles, each one detailing the horrors of the past year... George closes the file and puts it away. He goes to shut drawer, but stops when he sees something-- An old PHOTOGRAPH buried beneath a stack of papers... It shows TWENTY YOUNG SOLDIERS standing at the top of a D HILL with an AMERICAN FLAG billowing overhead. A LEGENDARY FIGURE stands in the center-- His thick moustache and coke-bottle glasses identify him clearly as a caption would: President Theodore Roosevelt And then George sees two familiar faces in the back row: FRANK SULLIVAN and TOM DONOVAN; each twenty years old...

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?! George looks up and finds his wife standing at the door--

dialogues.speaker: SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be going through Frank's things. George hands her the photograph--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If you had a picture of yourself with the President, would you hide it away in a goddamn desk drawer? Sue stares at the picture, suddenly overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He left you for that war. Least he could do is put it on display. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Beat) I wonder what else he’s hiding... George stands up and leaves the room as Sue quietly wince from the pain of old wounds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WORK HORSES lurch forward, pulling tightly against long CHAINS running beneath the surface of the lake... Frank, Tom, Nathan, Patrick, and the other SEARCHERS watc the horses move forward, one laborous step at a time... Nathan seems excited, the others concerned. Whatever thes horses are pulling, it appears to be quite heavy... And then, suddenly-- A bullet-ridden MODEL-T FORD breaks through the surface.. The men slowly gather around as the car comes to shore. T peer through the shattered windows, recoiling in horror-- Two DEAD MEN are slumped in the front seat; their bodies destroyed by gunfire, their faces unrecognizable...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Nathan, hand me their wallets. Nathan glances at Tom, the excitement gone from his face. I really have to? Tom’s dark eyes give him the answer... Nathan takes a deep breath and reaches inside the car. Hi hand reappears, clutching two leather WALLETS... Tom steps forward and flips them both open. Each wallet carries a BADGE. The dead men were federal agents.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOWNSPEOPLE stand outside, watching with grave concern as PINEWOOD COFFINS get stacked outside the FUNERAL HOME...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli Peterson looks up as the DOORBELL chimes. Deputies Patrick & Nathan step into the office--  40.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: How are ya, Eli?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Oh, just waiting for the telephone man to get here so I can retire... (Glances out the window) You've had a busy day. Patrick nods and hands Eli a slip of paper--

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: We need to wire this information to to Kansas City right away.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Folks are talking about some kind of shooting out at the Sullivan Ranch...

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: We’re not sure, but it needs to stay quiet. Let us know the instant you get a response, alright? Eli nods and watches the two deputies leave. He looks dow and reads the wire...his eyes suddenly go wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli steps into the street, completely dazed. He watches t two coffins disappear inside the funeral home... Then he turns and sees TOWNSPEOPLE standing outside; whispering, pointing...the fear already taking hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue stands by the window, staring at the photograph. Fran young face is enough to knock the wind out of her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Tom sit beneath a jeweled sky, their horses kic and snorting in the cold evening air... Frank stares at the wallets of the two dead men--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (Reading their IDs) Neither of ‘em made it to thirty.  41.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Too many young people dying these days. That’s for sure. Frank nods sadly and gives the wallets back to Tom. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’1l1 come back tomorrow and help you move the girl into town. (Off Frank’s look) She can’t stay here. This place is the perfect spot for an ambush. Frank looks around for a moment, then slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Edward will be with me, so we can get his help, as well.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don't forget to ask about his blood type, alright?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Sure. And I’1ll have Farley make an announcement. Maybe someone in town knows. Worth a shot. (Beat) I could have my deputies stay here tonight. Incase whoever did this decides to come back. Frank stares at the dark forest, considering the offer--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If someone was going to show up, they would've done it by now.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Alright... Tom sees Sue Fowler standing in Frank’s window. He nods--

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should've seen her during the crisis. It reminded me of you, quiet honestly. Charging with Roosevelt up San Juan Hill... (Beat) People were dying all around her. One after another. But she just kept going. Fearless. Frank looks up at Sue. Tom stares at his friend--  42.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ever regret going to the Philippines...after Cuba?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I did what my country asked...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If you had come home, she might not have married George...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t regret the years I had with my wife, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: No one’s saying you do. But you deserve to be happy. So does she... (Glances at Sue, then) Nobody’d hold it against you. Nobody who matters, anyway. Tom kicks his horse and gallops away. Frank watches his friend disappear in the darkness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Fowler sits at the table, nervously rubbing his ha It’s been awhile since he’s had a drink... .--and the shakes are starting to set in.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s getting pretty late. You gonna head home? George looks up at Frank with eyes darker than the room--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If my wife’s staying, I’m staying. Frank stares at George. His fist clenches again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue leans against the wall, deep in thought. The sound of faint moaning causes her to suddenly turn around... The young girl is awake. Sue rushes to her bedside--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Hi...can you hear me? What’s your name? Can you tell me? It’s alright if you don’t remember...  43. The girl’s eyes flutter as she fights to stay conscious. heart is racing and her nerves are on fire... SUE (CONT’D) Here, let me give you something for the pain... Sue fills a SYRINGE with MORPHINE-- SUE (CONT’D) This is going to sting a little... She pierces the skin. The girl suddenly screams and pulls away, causing the needle to break off in her arm... SUE (CONT’D) Shit... (Yelling) Frank?! George?! (Top of her lungs)

dialogues.speaker: I NEED HELP UP HERE
dialogues.text: FOOTSTEPS come flying up the stairs and race down the hal Frank bursts into the room with George close behind... SUE (CONT’D) Hold her down... Frank steps forward and restrains the girl so that Sue ca dig the bloody needle out of her vein...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: No...shtfpfff...nasths...please... no...ugh, humph...God, no... George stares at the girl, trying to make sense of her wo YOUNG GIRL (CONT’D) No, please...somebody...help! (And then, screaming) Getaway! You fuck! Help me! Shit! Motherfucker! ! God...damnit! The young girl suddenly grabs Frank by the hand, bracing herself against him, holding on for dear life... Sue pulls the needle out of the girl’s arm. Blood sprays everywhere, soaking the bed sheets. The girl screams-- Sue fills another SYRINGE and sticks the exposed arm. The girl moans as narcotic burns through her veins... She slowly lets go of Frank’s hand...and falls asleep.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jesus, where did she come from? (a moment, then) Been awhile since I heard screaming like that...almost forgot what it sounded like. Frank looks down at his empty hand as Sue goes to the win She suddenly steps back, her face frozen in fear--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Frank? There’s somebody outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SILHOUETTED MAN stands on the front porch... Frank comes out the side door holding a rifle in his arms swings around, about to pull the trigger--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Don’t move! The man freezes, then turns slightly...it’s Eli Peterson.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, Eli...

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Didn’t mean to scare. Frank catches his breath and climbs the porch steps. The on his face says it all: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Folks in town are saying this girl looks like my granddaughter... (Beat) Can I see her? Frank stares at Eli...and finally nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands with Eli at the girl’s bedside, watching as old man stares down in quiet disbelief--

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: Quite something, isn’t it? (Off Frank’s look) I know you’re not a religious man, Frank...but it’s hard not see the hand of providence in this.  Eli looks 45.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If you say so, Eli... (a moment, then) What are people saying in town?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: A lot of rumor and...speculation. Folks see pinewood coffins stacked outside the funeral home and... (Chokes back emotion) .--old feelings rise up. at Frank as the fire crackles behind them--

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I still haven't forgiven you. (Off Frank’s look) For not letting me see my daughter before you put her in the ground. Frank glances at Sue, standing quietly near the door. BEA

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It was all pretty sudden, Eli. There wasn’t much time.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: It’s almost worse imagining it. You hear about people’s hair turning white and falling out. Their lungs filling with fluid, black like oil. Drowning in open air...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It’s better you remember them the way they were. I didn’t want you seeing them...like that.

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) What kind of disease spares the elderly and attacks the young? Frank stares at his father-in-law, unable to answer. Eli looks right at Frank and points to the young girl--

dialogues.speaker: ELI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frank...save her. And with that, Eli turns and leaves the room. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Sullivan slumps in a leather chair, fast asleep.  46. The house is dark and quiet, except for the soft whisper tiny candle flame dancing on a nearby table... Suddenly, the candle goes out...and a thin trail of smoke floats to the ceiling as the room grows that much darker- Frank Sullivan suddenly opens his eyes. He sees a STRANGE SHAPE lurking just across the room... A YOUNG WOMAN. Standing by the window. Frank slowly gets up and walks towards her. The girl ling for a moment, then spins towards him... It’s his DAUGHTER. She looks right at him through hollow eyes, her face rotting with MAGGOTS and WORMS--

dialogues.speaker: KATHRYN SULLIVAN
dialogues.text: Father... Frank Sullivan suddenly bolts awake! He gasps and falls o of his chair, struggling to catch his breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue Fowler sleeps peacefully; the fading light of a dying fire dancing softly against her eyelids. Frank covers her with a blanket, then crosses the room an stokes the fire back to life... He glances up at a FAMILY PORTRAIT hanging on the wall, t looks down at the young girl, fighting for her life... This is a line in the sand moment for Frank Sullivan-- He was powerless to save his wife and daughter. He had no control over what happened to his son. But Frank can save this girl...even if it means risking his life. He takes a deep breath as the fire roars behind him. We c almost see Eli’s command taking hold in his mind: Save he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Farley stands behind the PULPIT, addressing his CONGREGATION. Less than half the pews are filled...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: Before we begin, I’ve been asked to make an announcement. As I’m sure many of you have heard...there’s a young girl out at the Sullivan Ranch who’s been badly hurt...  47.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Tom sits beside Rosaleigh, watching as many CONGREGANTS glance at each other suspiciously... REVEREND FARLEY (CONT’D) She was viciously attacked Friday night...and is in desperate need of a blood transfusion. Is anyone here aware of their blood type? People slowly shake their heads. Tom watches, disappointe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eli Peterson comes into the office and finds the telegrap eerily quiet. No messages have come through... Eli stares at empty tray, clearly alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Sullivan stands outside, chopping firewood as the morning sun breaks free of the horizon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Fowler watches Frank from the window. He nervously rubs his hands, which have started to tremble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks to the girl’s bedroom and peers inside. Sue swapping out her bandages. George clears his throat--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ‘Think I’m gonna head into town... You need anything? Sue glances at his trembling hands and shakes her head. George turns and leaves without saying another word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Rosaleigh come outside and overhear Reverend Farl talking to a FARMER and his WIFE (Both 50s)--

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: .»..Maybe you could ask Joey when he gets in next week?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Our Joey’s been through enough. We don’t want him mixed up in this...  48. The farmer and his wife turn and walk away. Farley watche them go, then glances at Tom and Rosaleigh--

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: Seems to be the general feeling, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: They're just scared...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND FARLEY
dialogues.text: Bullet-ridden cars and bloody corpses...not all fear is irrational, you know? Rosaleigh glances at her husband. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. A distant TRAIN WHISTLE suddenly shrieks and Rosaleigh pu Tom away. Farley watches them race towards the station... INT. LEONARD DUSCHENE’S ROOM -- THAT MOMENT Leonard watches Tom and Rosaleigh charge down the street another TRAIN WHISTLE blows, already getting closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosaleigh glances up at Leonard's window as the train whi fades. Her face darkens. She turns to Tom--

dialogues.speaker: ROSALEIGH
dialogues.text: Farley has a point, you know? (Nods at Leonard’s window) A lot of people would still be alive if we’d just shut our doors and kept everyone out... Tom glances at his wife, but doesn’t respond. He sees Eli Peterson up ahead, waving for them to come over...

dialogues.speaker: ROSALEIGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You better know what you’re doing, especially if you’re getting Edward involved. We’re the only family in this town who hasn’t lost anyone...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You think I’ve forgotten that?

dialogues.speaker: ROSALEIGH
dialogues.text: Just make sure you don’t.  49. Tom nods “alright” as Eli steps forward to meet them--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: What is it? We get a response?

dialogues.speaker: ELI
dialogues.text: No, that’s just it. There’s been nothing. No word. (Then, off Tom’s look) We wired to say that we found two dead federal agents...don’t you think that’s the sort of thing that would get an answer right away? Tom glances at Rosaleigh as another train whistle shrieks

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I’m sure we’ll hear something soon. Keep me posted, okay? Eli reluctantly nods as Tom and Rosaleigh walk away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TRAIN pulls into the station and TWO DOUGHBOYS step ont the platform. A gathering CROWD bursts into APPLAUSE-- EDWARD DONOVAN (Tom’s son, 20) is one of the soldiers. He walks with a faint limp, searching for his parents...

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Edward! Edward! Tom and Rosaleigh are standing up ahead. They throw their arms around their son and hold on for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: TOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s so good to see you...

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Tom takes a step back and stares at son, impressed by the dapper looking kid wearing a man’s uniform--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: My word...welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PATRONS stand at the window, watching the celebration... George Fowler suddenly bursts into the saloon. Everyone watches as the BARTENDER (50s) pours his usual drink--  50.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sam. Leave the bottle. Sam nods and steps aside. Charlie Foster and Ben Sanderfo (the two ‘regulars’) stand up and approach--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Heya, George. Didn’t see ya come in yesterday. We were getting worried. LAUGHTER ripples through the saloon as Charlie and Ben surround George; two bad angels perched on his shoulder-- CHARLIE (CONT’D) ‘Been out at the Sullivan Ranch? What’s the story?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It’s nothing. No big deal...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: No big deal? I hear you guys pulled a shot-up car out of the lake. (Leans closer) Who's in the coffins, George?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To hell with the coffins, who’s the girl? She sick?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, she ain’t sick. Just shot to hell. Sue’s taking care of her... George throws back his drink and pours himself another--

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know Frank’s got a picture of himself with the president?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You mean Roosevelt? Sure. Frank charged up San Juan Hill. He’s a genuine piece of American history.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s nothing. After Cuba, most of the Rough Riders came home. But not Frank. He went to the Philippines and fought the insurgency there.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I guess one war against Spain wasn’t enough...  51.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can you imagine? Not even Hearst’s papers could spin that war. I bet Frank saw one or two things over there. Yes, sir...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It all worked out though. Frank got his war. And George got Sue.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Except now Emily Sullivan is dead. And Sue is back at Frank’s house... George looks up at Charlie, his eyes wounded and foggy.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Hey, George...you gonna tell us what we want to know or what? George hesitates, then pours another drink as more footst approach. His eyes suddenly close...and surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue comes downstairs and fills a PITCHER with water... She notices the PHONOGRAPH on the counter and starts flip through records...suddenly stopping at one in particular- AFTER YOU'VE GONE by Marion Harris The sound of an opening door causes Sue to look up. Frank comes inside, his arms filled with FIREWOOD. BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: George left?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he had to go into town... (Holds up the record) I remember this one. Frank sets down the firewood and slowly approaches--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: They played it the night you left. I don’t think I’ve heard it since. Frank smiles, then takes the record from her hands and pl it on the wheel. He lowers the needle gently--  52. After a few bursts of static, the song begins to play-- Frank finally finds the courage to look at Sue. The lyric pull them together and they slowly start to dance...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: If I tell you something, will you promise not to think less of me?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: The other night...I wanted to dance with you. (then, off her silence) Did you hear what I said, Sue? They spin towards CAMERA. Sue’s eyes are closed--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (Softly) I heard you. The song winds down and comes to an end, replaced once ag by the crisp static of the spinning wheel... Frank and Sue slowly lean in, just about to kiss...when they're suddenly interrupted by a knock at the door. Frank forces himself to turn away and leave the room. Sue stares at the record spinning on the wheel. She slowl lifts the needle...and the house plunges to silence. Sue takes a deep breath and goes to the window-- The Donovan family is standing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands with Tom, Rosaleigh, Edward, and Sue; a heav silence weighing between them... Edward stares at PICTURES hanging on the wall, focusing o Kathryn, beautiful in black & white--

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (To Frank) I don’t know if you were ever aware, but...I carried quite a torch for your daughter when we were in school. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to tell William that when we got back, I was gonna call on her. He didn’t like that very much. Frank smiles, but doesn’t respond. Edward turns and limps across the room. Everyone watches. Nobody says a word. Edward reaches the counter and opens his bag-- There’s newspaper lying on top of his things. Edward take out and sets it aside, then reaches deeper into the bag-- He pulls out a WATCH and a few LETTERS, then gives them t Frank as if they meant everything in the world--

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These were his. Frank takes a deep breath, clutching his son’s things.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He has a beautiful grave. Just outside of Fromelles. It’s about the nicest spot you could ask for. (a moment, then) He talked about you all the time. Bragged about how his dad got to the top of San Juan Hill before Roosevelt did. (Beat) All he wanted was make you proud.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I was already proud of him. He didn’t have to go to war for that. Edward slowly nods. Sue cautiously steps forward--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Edward, you don’t know your blood type, by any chance...do you?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Dad said you were looking for a donor...I’m AB-Positive. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (To Tom) Morgan make the announcement?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, but nobody’s coming forward. And the next batch of soldiers aren’t due in until next week...  54.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: O-negative blood is pretty rare. There weren't many guys in my regiment who had it. Sue nods, clearly disappointed. Tom checks his watch--

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We should probably get going. Frank glances at Sue, then reluctantly nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young girl lies in bed; her breathing weak and shallo Sue Fowler stands nearby, quietly packing her things...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ready? Sue looks up and sees Frank standing at the door. She nod then turns and gives the girl another shot of MORPHINE.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s she doing?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Blood pressure’s low. Pulse is high. All we can do is keep her sedated...and hope for the best. Frank stares at Sue, reading between the lines--

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: She's not going to make it, is she?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) With the amount of blood she’s lost and no donors coming forward...it’s probably just a matter of time. Frank stares at the girl and finally nods. BEAT. SUE (CONT’D) If it’s any consolation, I know how you feel. I was looking forward to saving a patient for a change. Frank glances at the FAMILY PORTRAIT on the wall. Suddenl Sue realizes: it’s more than just some patient for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
